Question: What are the sources that confirm the video's true origin and debunk the claim of Trump's Maui visit?

Queries.Query 1: fact check Trump Maui visit August 2023 wildfires
Queries.Query 2: Trump video origin Beauregard Alabama disaster 2019

Query 1.title: Does Video Show Trump Visiting Maui After August 2023 Fires ...
Query 1.snippet: Aug 17, 2023 ... Fact Check. Does Video Show Trump Visiting Maui After August 2023 Fires? The claim spread after massive fires that burned in Maui in August ...

content.content: The claim spread after massive fires that burned in Maui in August 2023 left more than 100 people dead at the time of this writing. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ### Published Aug. 17, 2023 Claim: Online video showed U.S. President Donald Trump visiting Maui in the aftermath of the August 2023 wildfires. Context The footage actually showed Trump visiting Beauregard, Alabama in 2019 after a tornado killed nearly two dozen people in the area. In August 2023, social media users shared a video clip purporting to show that former U.S. President Donald Trump had visited Maui, an island in Hawaii, in the aftermath of that left a swath of destruction and more than 100 people dead as of this writing. "The People's President, Donald J. Trump and our Beautiful First Lady Melania Trump, checking up on the people of Maui after the #MauiFires," an X (formerly known as Twitter) post on Aug. 16, 2023. According to the post, the video showed Trump and his wife, former first lady Melania Trump, walking through wreckage with a FEMA truck in the background, as well as Trump speaking to a group of people saying he had met some of the survivors and family members. > TRUMP Visits Maui Hawaii, A Real President Truly cares.???? > > — STEVE #DREAM BIG...just enjoy the moment (@stevehalilovic) In addition, we found the same claim being trumpeted on other social media platforms, like . This footage didn't show Trump visiting Maui. Instead, this was footage from when he visited Beauregard, Alabama, in 2019, after a tornado killed nearly two dozen people in the area. In the video clip, Trump is heard saying: > These are incredible people. We just met some of the survivors and family members, and what they've been through is incredible. One woman lost 10 people in ... [Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Snopes is widely recognized as a reliable fact-checking website. It has a long history of investigating rumors, urban legends, and misinformation, providing thorough and well-researched analyses. Its methodology includes sourcing credible evidence and documenting claims in a transparent manner. While it is regarded as one of the best fact-checking sites, its reliance on user-submitted content can occasionally lead to disputes over objectivity, hence the slight deduction in score.

ContentScore.Newness Justification: The article from Snopes was published on August 17, 2023, which is relatively recent and directly related to the events following the Maui wildfires. Given the current date is July 2024, this article still holds significant relevance in terms of timeliness.
ContentScore.Relevance Justification: This evidence directly addresses the claim regarding Trump's supposed visit to Maui and explicitly tests the authenticity of the video. It confirms that the video is old footage from 2019, making it critical for clarifying the misleading claim.

Query 1.title: Video falsely claims Trump visited Maui amid wildfires| Fact check
Query 1.snippet: Aug 18, 2023 ... There are no credible reports that Trump has gone to visit Maui amid the island's wildfires. However, the former president did give a video ...

content.content: Video falsely claims Trump visited Maui amid wildfires| Fact check =============== ONLY AT USA TODAY: OUR PORTFOLIO: : 68°F Sunny") fact-checking Add Topic Video of Trump visiting a storm-destroyed area is from 2019, not Maui fires | Fact check ======================================================================================== Gabrielle Settles] USA TODAY 0:03 1:16 AD SKIP The claim: Video shows Trump visiting Maui after wildfires ---------------------------------------------------------- An Aug. 16 Facebook video (, ) shows a TikTok video that features former President Donald Trump and former first lady Melania Trump walking past a FEMA truck in a disaster-struck area and talking with people in a building filled with supplies and clothes. “THE PEOPLE'S PRESIDENT,” reads text on the screen. “Thank you Mr. Trump for checking on the people of Maui!” The Facebook video was shared over 900 times in one day, while the original TikTok video has been shared more than 7,000 times. **Follow us on Facebook!** Our rating: False ----------------- The video is years old and shows the former president's 2019 visit to Alabama after a tornado damaged part of the state. Trump has not visited the Hawaiian island of Maui following the devastating wildfires there that killed more than 100 in early August. Video shows Trump visiting Alabama in 2019 ------------------------------------------ At least have died in wildfires that consumed parts of Maui, the second-largest of the Hawaiian islands, since . But there is no evidence the former president has visited the island. The video shared on Facebook shows then-president Trump delivering remarks to a group of people at Providence Baptist Church in Opelika, Alabama, on March 8, 2019, after the area was struck by a tornado that caused serious damage and left injured. The church was serving as a disaster relief center for those affected. The White House shared footage of the visit on the same day. ... [Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: USA Today is a major American news outlet known for its generally accurate reporting and fact-checking initiatives. It has a dedicated fact-checking section that evaluates claims made in the news. Although the site maintains high standards of journalism, it can sometimes prioritize headlines over comprehensive investigative work, leading to occasional oversights. Nonetheless, it is a solid source for checking facts, particularly in the context of trending news stories.

ContentScore.Newness Justification: The USA Today article was published on August 18, 2023, making it quite timely relative to the claim regarding Trump's actions after the wildfires. However, it is slightly less fresh compared to some other sources from the same period.
ContentScore.Relevance Justification: This evidence directly addresses the false claim of Trump's visit to Maui, confirming that there are no credible reports of such a visit. It is highly relevant in assessing the truthfulness of the claim.

Query 1.title: Post Makes False Claim About Children Missing After Maui Wildfires ...
Query 1.snippet: Sep 20, 2023 ... McDonald, Jessica. “High Winds, Drought Conditions Led to Maui Fires, No Evidence Intentionally Set.” FactCheck.org. 18 Aug 2023. Izevbigie, ...

content.content: By Blossom Izevbigie Posted on September 20, 2023 The wildfires in Maui caused widespread destruction on the island and claimed the lives of 97 people. The Maui Police Department and the FBI have released the list of 31 individuals still unaccounted for following the fires. Yet an Instagram post falsely claims “over 1,000 children are missing.” The wildfires in Maui started on Aug. 8 and burned for days. They consumed more than 2,000 homes and other structures and largely destroyed Lahaina, a historic community that was hit the hardest by the fires. Following weeks of difficult work using DNA and other methods to confirm and identify the victims of the Maui wildfires, officials announced on Sept. 15 that the death toll was 97, a lower figure than previously reported. Dr. Jeremy Stuelpnagel, the Maui medical examiner, said at a press conference that day, “because of the fire, because of the heat, because of the situation of this being a mass disaster, many of them are down to the bones — some are fragmented.” Stuelpnagel also said, “We’re trying every single modality we have to make sure that we identify these people. It does take a lot of time. This is a mass disaster.” The county of Maui has released reports on those still unaccounted for following the fires. As of Sept. 15, 31 individuals were reported missing from an initial list of more than 3,200 people. A list identifying the missing was released by the Maui Police Department and the FBI, with one person identified as a minor. But an online video, titled “Over 1,000 Missing Children in Maui,” falsely claims that 1,050 kids are “gone without a trace.” The video goes on to say, “They have absolutely no clue where these children are.” The numbers given in the video ... [Content truncated]

Its work is thorough and methodical, with a strong emphasis on accuracy and transparency. It is a respected authority in the field of fact-checking, particularly for political claims, which grants it a strong score.

ContentScore.Newness Justification: This article from FactCheck.org was published on September 20, 2023. While still within weeks of the relevant events, it is less timely than the August publications, but it is still contemporary to the context of the wildfires and Trump's alleged visit.
ContentScore.Relevance Justification: This evidence deals with misinformation regarding the Maui wildfires, but does not specifically address Trump's claimed visit. It provides context but is not as directly related to the claim as the previous sources.

Query 2.title: Trump signs Bibles during disaster tour of Alabama - POLITICO
Query 2.snippet: Mar 8, 2019 ... 03/08/2019 03:42 PM EST ... After surveying damage from above in a helicopter ride, Trump arrived in Beauregard, Alabama, a rural community hit ...

content.content: Trump signs Bibles during disaster tour of Alabama - POLITICO =============== Skip to Main Content ============================= * * * * Search WASHINGTON & POLITICS --------------------- * * * * * * * 2024 ELECTIONS -------------- * * * * * * STATE POLITICS & POLICY ----------------------- * * * * GLOBAL POLITICS & POLICY ------------------------ * * * * POLICY NEWS ----------- * * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWSLETTERS ----------- * * * * * * * * COLUMNISTS ---------- * * * * * * * * SERIES & MORE ------------- * * * * * * * * POLITICO Live ------------- * * Follow us --------- * * * * * Trump signs Bibles during disaster tour of Alabama -------------------------------------------------- ! President Donald Trump passed wrecked homes and fallen trees en route to a Baptist church in Alabama, where he thanked volunteers and commented on the destruction after a tornado devastated the area last week. | Carolyn Kaster/AP Photo By Katie Galioto 03/08/2019 03:42 PM EST * * * * Link Copied * * * * President Donald Trump on Friday extended an unusual gesture as he sought to comfort Alabama residents devastated by a tornado outbreak last weekend — he signed Bibles. Trump offered up his autograph to first responders and survivors at a Baptist church in the eastern part of the state, after tornadoes left a path of destruction nearly a mile wide and killed 23 people last Sunday. After surveying damage from above in a helicopter ride, Trump arrived in Beauregard, Alabama, a rural community hit the hardest. Trump passed wrecked homes and fallen trees en route to the Baptist church, where he thanked volunteers and commented on the destruction. “We saw things that you wouldn’t believe,” ... [Content truncated]

ContentScore.Relevance Justification: The evidence discusses Trump's visit to Beauregard, Alabama, after a tornado, which directly relates to clarifying the video's origin compared to the claim regarding Maui.

Query 2.title: Trump Surveys Tornado Damage in Alabama, and Signs Some ...
Query 2.snippet: Mar 8, 2019 ... BEAUREGARD, Ala. — President Trump offered words of comfort on Friday for Alabama's tornado survivors, scrawling his presidential signature ...

content.content: Advertisement You have a preview view of this article while we are checking your access. When we have confirmed access, the full article content will load. ! President Trump departed from Joint Base Andrews on Friday, on his way to visit communities in Alabama that were devastated by a tornado outbreak.Credit...Sarah Silbiger/The New York Times * March 8, 2019 BEAUREGARD, Ala. — President Trump offered words of comfort on Friday for Alabama’s tornado survivors, scrawling his presidential signature on some of their Bibles as they moved close to him at a church that provided shelter during the storm and was now doling out emergency aid. “We saw things you wouldn’t believe,” Mr. Trump said as he stood amid the wreckage and rubble of Beauregard, the site of the nation’s deadliest tornado in six years. Mr. Trump’s travels through Alabama — in a helicopter for an aerial tour, through a debris-strewn neighborhood and later at the Baptist church that has been a hub of relief efforts — were a welcome presence in Beauregard, where at least one of the storm’s victims had flown a Trump campaign flag outside his home and where Mr. Trump captured most of the vote. A few hundred people lined the two-lane county road by Providence Baptist Church to try to glimpse Mr. Trump from the grassy shoulder or the nearby cemetery. During his stop at Providence, Mr. Trump met with relatives of the 23 storm victims, as well as volunteers and emergency workers. Dressed in his presidency’s iteration of what political strategists sometimes describe as “disaster casual” — a windbreaker, showing a fraction of an open-collar shirt, and khaki pants — he posed for pictures and signed autographs, including at least one in a 12-year-old boy’s Bible. “We couldn’t get here fast enough,” Mr. Trump said ... [Content truncated]

It serves as a reliable source for news, providing insight into political and social issues while actively seeking to expose misinformation.

ContentScore.Newness Justification: Published on March 8, 2019. It discusses Trump's actions after the tornado but is somewhat dated.
ContentScore.Relevance Justification: The article is relevant as it addresses Trump's response to a specific disaster, helping clarify the misinformation about his supposed visit to Maui.

QA.Question: What are the sources that confirm the video's true origin and debunk the claim of Trump's Maui visit?
QA.Answer:
The sources that confirm the video's true origin and debunk the claim of Trump's visit to Maui are as follows:

1. **Snopes Fact Check**: According to Snopes, the footage incorrectly attributed to Trump's visit to Maui actually shows him visiting Beauregard, Alabama, in 2019, after a tornado disaster. The video was shared widely on social media after the wildfires in Maui, misleading many into believing it was a recent event. The original footage shows Trump speaking after a different disaster, and not in the context of the August 2023 wildfires in Maui.

2. **USA Today Fact Check**: In a similar analysis, USA Today corroborated that there are no credible reports of Trump's visit to Maui amid the wildfires. The video being circulated was confirmed to be from Trump's 2019 visit to Alabama. They specifically note that the video shows him at a disaster relief center following a tornado, thus providing clear evidence that the footage is old and misrepresented as a recent event relating to Maui.

Based on the evidence from these reputable fact-checking sources, the claim that Donald Trump visited Maui after the August 2023 wildfires is false, and the video in question is from a different event entirely.
